Wenxian Li acknowledges research support from the Program for Professors with Special Appointments (Eastern Scholar: TP2014041) at Shanghai Institutions of Higher Learning . Wenxian Li is a Professor at the School for Materials Science and Engineering, Shanghai University. Dr. Li received his Ph.D. from the University of Wollongong, Australia, in 2010. He got the Australian Postdoctoral Fellowship (Industrial) supported by the Australian Research Council in 2012 and then got financial support from the Australian Renewable Energy Agency as a Postdoctoral Fellowship. He joined the University of Western Sydney as a lecturer in the Solar Energy Technologies Group in November 2012. Graphical abstract The underlying relationships among HER mechanisms, the surface/interface effect of MoS2, and HER performance are reviewed based on the analysis of the critical parameters, such as conductivity, active sites, ΔG H, and surface hydrophilicity. Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2)-based materials as the non-noble metal catalysts have displayed the potential capability to drive electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) for green hydrogen production along with their intrinsic activity, tunable electronic properties, low cost, and abundance reserves, which have attracted intensive attention as alternatives to the low-abundance and high-cost platinum-based catalysts. However, their insufficient catalytic HER activities and stability are the major challenges for them to become practically applicable. Hereby, the MoS2-based electrocatalysts for HER are comprehensively reviewed to explain the fundamental science behind the manipulations of the crystal structure, microstructure, surface, and interface of MoS2 in order to enhance its catalytic performance through changing the electrical conductivity, the number of active sites, surface wettability, and the Gibbs free energy for hydrogen adsorption (ΔG H). Recent studies in surface/interface engineering, such as phase engineering, defect engineering, morphology design, and heterostructure construction, are analyzed to reveal the state-of-the-art strategies for designing and preparing the cost-effective and high-performance MoS2-based catalysts through optimizing the charge transfer, surface-active sites, ΔG H, and surface hydrophilicity. Lastly, the perspectives, challenges, and future research directions of HER electrocatalysis are also given to facilitate the further research and development of HER catalysts. Keywords Surface/interface engineering Hydrogen evolution reaction Molybdenum disulfide Mechanisms 1 Introduction The development of sustainable energy sources without carbon footprints such as solar, tidal, wind, waterfall, and geothermal energies, has attracted intensive interest in recent years with the growing concerns about the global shortages of fossil fuels and the environmental pollution problems [1–4]. However, there is a significant challenge in directly inputting and transmitting the electrical energy generated from these intermittent energy sources into the existing electricity grids. In this regard, developing energy storage technologies to efficiently store these electrical energies, including supercapacitors, batteries, and water-electrolysis to produce hydrogen, are critically needed [5–8]. In particular, water-electrolysis to produce hydrogen (H2) has been recognized as a feasible and sustainable option because of the widespread electrical source, zero-emission reaction process, and high-purity product of H2 [9–12]. In a water-electrolysis cell, the cathode process is the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [13–15]. The anode process is the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [16]. Both of them require electrocatalysts to catalyze the chemical reactions with fast reaction kinetics [17–21]. Therefore, designing and synthesizing cost-efficiency and active electrocatalysts are essential for the large-scale manufacture of hydrogen through water-electrolysis [22–24]. Currently, the most popular commercial catalysts for HER include Pt/C (33 mV at 10 mA cm−2, 25 mV dec−1) [25] and Pd (110 mV at 10 mA cm−2, 87.8 mV dec−1) [26]. However, the low earth abundance of noble metals has significantly restricted their large industrial-scale applications [27,28]. Therefore, developing electrocatalysts with low mass loading of noble metals or even without noble metals is desired and essential to achieving affordable hydrogen production via electrolysis. To date, promising substitutes of noble metal catalysts include layered transition metal oxides [29–35], transition metal carbides (TMCs) [36–40], transition metal phosphides [41–44], transition metal nitrides (TMNs) [25,45], and transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) [46–54]. Layered metal oxides are environmentally friendly, cost-effective, accessible, and stable natures [55]. However, most metal oxides possess sluggish reaction kinetics and low electrical conductivity. Transitional metal carbides show high electrical conductivity, high mechanical strength, reasonable stability, and favorable intermediates-adsorption properties, but their interfacial reaction kinetics and catalytic activity are significantly worse compared with Pt-based catalyst materials. Transition metal phosphides are usually abundant, low-cost, and exhibit highly catalytic performance while their relatively unstable structures, agglomeration, and poisonous characteristics in their synthesis obstruct their widespread application. Transition metal nitrides usually have great electrical conductivity and corrosion resistance, and high mechanical hardness, but their HER activities are not particularly high. As a typical TMD, molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) with great potential as HER catalyst has attracted intensive attention in recent years [56–66]. MoS2 possesses intrinsic HER activity, but it is insufficient for mass production because of the low electrical conductivity, strong tendency towards agglomeration, low mechanical stability, and inert basal plane of MoS2. Surface/interface engineering could improve the HER performance of MoS2-based materials by overcoming these drawbacks of MoS2-based HER catalysts. Several material optimization strategies based on surface/interface engineering have been proposed for optimizing the electrical conductivity, inhibiting material agglomeration, increasing stability, decreasing the energy barriers of HER, and accelerating the catalytic HER process, as summarized in Fig. 1 . These methods include phase engineering [67–69], defect engineering [70,71], morphology design [72], and heterostructure construction [73–79]. The fabrication and application of MoS2-based catalysts have attracted significant attention in terms of the manipulations of electronic structures, the active catalytic centers, defect designs, synthetic methods, applications, etc. [80–84]. Chia et al. [80] summarized various strategies for enhancing HER on transition-metal dichalcogenides, such as MoS2, WS2, MoSe2, and MoSe2 including doping TMDs with Fe, Co, and Ni, synthesizing TMD hybrids on various catalyst supports, and increasing the number of active sites in the TMDs. It highlighted that further research should focus on the control of the phase transitions between TMDs’ metallic and semiconducting phases and the inherent electrochemical properties of TMDs. Jayabal et al. [81] reviewed the synthesis, characterization, and potential application areas of 1T-MoS2 and pointed out that the interface can be further studied in detail in future research to design unique high-performance 1T-MoS2 catalysts. The mechanism behind sustainable performance and the underlying structure-property relationship are still unclear and require further exploration. Zhu et al. [82] systemically summarized the relationship between the composition, structure, synthetic method, morphology, and activity of the MoS2-based electrocatalysts. The challenges for sustainable hydrogen generation include (i) the clarification of the mechanistic research at the atomic-scale level of MoS2-based electrocatalysts; (ii) in situ characterization techniques for the detection of active sites are still highly desirable; (iii) accurately comparing the performance of various catalysts is difficult for the lack of a universal standard. Wei et al. [83] discussed the experimental setup of electrocatalysis, providing some common guidelines which include the cell design, counter electrode, and reference electrode selection, working electrode preparation, data correction, as well as estimation of catalysts surface area. These reviews have described the physicochemical property, HER mechanism, and material improvement strategies in detail. In this paper, the mechanisms of HER catalyzed by MoS2-based catalysts are summarized to show how the HER performances can be enhanced through modification of the structures and compositions of the catalysts with surface/interface engineering. The underlying relationships among HER mechanisms, the surface/interface effect of MoS2, and HER performances are reviewed based on the analysis of the critical parameters that determine the catalytic performances, including charge transfer, active sites, ΔG H, and surface hydrophilicity. These relationships are discussed in detail concerning the three elementary steps involved in HER (Volmer reaction, Heyrovsky or Tafel reaction, and release step) to highlight how structural modifications in the layered MoS2 are beneficial for it to achieve high catalytic HER performances. Three steps are involved in HER: electrochemical adsorption step (Volmer reaction), electrochemical or chemical desorption step (corresponding to Heyrovsky or Tafel reaction), and release step, which is affected by the conductivity, wettability, the number and intrinsic activity of the active sites, and ΔG H of the MoS2 catalyst. Besides, the practical application of catalysts for HER should be sustainable and affordable, which requires lower overpotential for high-efficiency hydrogen production and good stability for the long-term HER process. Based on the optimization of these critical parameters, the optimizing strategies could boost the catalytic HER performance and are reviewed in this paper, including phase engineering, defect engineering, morphology control, and heterostructure construction, as illustrated in Fig. 1. The metallic 1T phase molybdenum disulfide possesses outstanding electronic conductivity and good wettability, leading to desirable electrochemical HER performances. We show that the electronic structure of MoS2 can be optimized through defect engineering to reach the optimum energetic balance between the adsorption and desorption of hydrogen intermediates. Thus the inert basal plane of MoS2 could be favourable for the hydrogen generation process. Two-dimension MoS2 tends to aggregate and stack. Controlling the morphologies of the MoS2 nanomaterials can expose more catalytic active sites to increase the specific areas of MoS2 thus accelerating fast ion/charge transfer at the interfaces. The abundant dangling bonds on the surface of MoS2 could provide sites for the connection between MoS2 and other materials, thus constructing the heterostructures. The construction of heterostructure will further confine the growth of MoS2 nanosheets to achieve a well-dispersed structure and produce more interfaces for enhancing interfacial electron transfer between semiconducting 2H phase MoS2 and the other components involved in the catalytic reactions. Combining these several strategies might remarkably improve the electrocatalytic performances. This review will deliver some insights into the design and optimization of MoS2-based catalysts even in the other energy conversion reactions. 2 The fundamental knowledge of MoS2 As a typical two-dimensional (2D) TMD, MoS2 monolayer consists of a trilayer structure with one layer of Mo atoms sandwiched between two layers of chalcogen S [85–88]. MoS2 has mostly active edges but neutral surfaces, which is similar to the other 2D materials including black phosphorus, silicene, graphene, antimonene, and borophene. These 2D materials may suffer from limitations because of their thermodynamically satisfied basal plane atoms. Nevertheless, the active edge planes and the adjustable band gap of MoS2 exhibit the enormous potential for electrocatalytic hydrogen generation [89]. As a polyphase material [90], the crystal structure of MoS2 includes the metastable phase of 1T, the thermodynamically stable phase of 2H, and the unstable phase of 3R. The bulk MoS2 is formed by stacked multiple trilayers and held together by van der Waals interaction [91,92]. The different phases of MoS2 have proven to exhibit different catalytic HER properties originating from the different metal coordination environments, as shown in Fig. 2 (a–c). The 1T-phase of MoS2 with octahedral metal coordination possesses metallic-like properties (Fig. 2d) [93], showing high electrical conductivity and electrocatalytic HER activity on basal planes [94,95]. The 2H– and 3R-phase of MoS2 are both semi-conducting with band gaps of 1.461 and 1.415 eV, respectively (Fig. 2e and f). The activity of 2H-MoS2 had been limited for decades due to its extremely inert basal planes until the theoretical calculations revealed that the edge planes were active for catalytic reactions [96,97]. 3R-MoS2 can hardly exist at ambient temperature. The MoS2-based catalysts are of particularly strong interest in the TMD family because they possess intrinsic activity induced by many active unsaturated sulfur atoms and Mo atoms in the material, which act as the catalytic active sites. MoS2 quantum dots [58], MoS2 monolayers [99], pure 1T-MoS2 [100], Co-doped mesoporous MoS2 foam [48], and many others, have been developed to enhance the exposure of the unsaturated atoms. These unsaturated atoms on MoS2 could interact with H to catalytically promote HER. However, HER catalyzed by MoS2 is significantly limited by the low electrical conductivity, strong tendency towards agglomeration, low mechanical stability, and inert basal plane of MoS2. More specifically: (1) The stable phase of bulk MoS2 is a semiconductor with a large bandgap of 1.8 eV [101], giving a large resistance in the vertical direction. MoS2 with a 6.5 Å van der Waals gap between each sheet results in the electron transfer about 2200 times faster along a basal plane direction than vertically across the van der Waals gap [102]. (2) As a two-dimensional material, MoS2 tends to aggregate and stack together to decrease its surface energy by exposing a less specific surface area (only about 4.36 m2 g−1) [103]. The small specific surface area severely limits the contact between the electrolyte and the catalysts in the HER; (3) The interlayers of MoS2 are bonded by the weak van der Waals interaction, which possesses lower stability compared to metal bonds in noble metals; (4) The edge planes of MoS2 with the Gibbs free energy of the adsorbed H (ΔG H) of 0.06 eV as shown in Fig. 3 when the basal planes of MoS2 with ΔG H of 1.92 eV, which means basal planes can hardly adsorb the H atom and are inactive towards HER, limiting the overall catalytic activity. 3 Electrocatalytic application of MoS2 3.1 The mechanisms of HER The process of electrocatalytic water splitting for hydrogen generation on the surface of materials includes three steps, i.e., adsorption, desorption, and release. The HER at the negative electrode (or cathode) is a two-electron transfer reaction [104,105] with intermediates such as the adsorbed hydrogen atom (Had) to produce hydrogen molecules. For further understanding of HER, two possible mechanisms, i.e., the Volmer-Tafel-release process and the Volmer-Heyrovsky-release process, have been proposed to describe the multi-step processes, as listed in the following equation [106]. In acidic (or neutral/alkaline) solution: Adsorption step (1) Volmer reaction: H3O+ (or H2O) + cat + e−→ cat-Had + H2O (or OH−) Desorption step (2) Heyrovsky reaction: cat-Had + H3O + (or H2O) + e−→cat---H2 + H2O (or OH−) (3) Tafel reaction: 2 cat-Had → cat---H2 + cat (4) Release step: cat---H2 → cat + H2↑ where the e− represents an electron, cat represents the catalyzed electrode surface, cat-Had represents an atom of hydrogen adsorbed on the catalyst surface, and cat---H2 represents a molecule physically adsorbed on the electrode surface. The Tafel slope is an inherent property of the reaction and indicates the rate-determining step of HER [107,108]. Regarding the catalytic HER process, three scenarios can be outlined as follows: (i) a slow Volmer reaction (1) leads to a large Tafel slope (~120 mV dec−1), (ii) a fast Volmer reaction followed by a limiting Heyrovsky reaction (2) gives a Tafel slope of ~40 mV dec−1, and (iii) the Tafel slope is ~30 mV dec−1 when a fast Volmer reaction followed by a rate-determining Tafel reaction (2). For the release step (4), H2 can be released from the electrode surface, which is mainly a physical process. The analysis of different Tafel slopes is helpful to understand the HER behavior on the MoS2-based electrode [82]. Regarding the Tafel slope values, HER catalyzed by MoS2 catalyst in alkaline solution showed a large Tafel slope of 129 mV dec−1, indicating that the rate-determining step is the Volmer reaction [109]. Chen et al. [110] synthesized a single-layer MoS2-coated Ag with a core–shell structure for accelerating the Volmer reaction to give a small Tafel slope of 41.1 mV dec−1. It was shown that controlling the morphologies of MoS2 or forming heterostructures between MoS2 and Ag could transform the catalytic pathway to a fast Volmer reaction followed by a slow Heyrovsky reaction [110]. Meng et al. [111] reported the catalyst of MoS2-confined single-atom rhodium could also drive a Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism by defect engineering. Feng et al. [112] reported a 1T-MoS2/CoS2 heterostructure that could deliver low Tafel slopes of 60 mV dec−1 in 1.0 M KOH and 43 mV dec−1 in 0.5 M H2SO4, respectively. As identified, the combination of phase control and heterostructure construction strategy could result in a fast Volmer reaction followed by a slow Heyrovsky reaction [25,113]. The research of mechanisms in hydrogen evolution reaction catalyzed by MoS2-based catalysts could guide the modification of the structures and compositions for HER performance enhancement. The electrocatalytic performance was classified and discussed in the following parts of the HER process. 3.2 Electrocatalytic performance of HER The HER performance of MoS2 can be characterized by different techniques, either experimentally or theoretically, for every step discussed in Subsection 2.1 above. To better understand the catalyzed HER, Fig. 4 summarizes the detailed catalysis process and the process parameters affecting the mechanism of the HER. 3.2.1 Adsorption step In the adsorption step, the possible mechanism is the Volmer reaction on the active sites of the MoS2 catalyst loaded on the electrode surface. The adsorbed protons on the catalyst can couple with the electron to form cat-Had (Fig. 5 a) [114]. The conductivity and ΔG H of the catalyst are two key factors influencing this process. Normally, good conductivity can facilitate charge transfer to active sites on the catalysts. However, the semi-conductive MoS2 has a large charge resistance of 83.7 Ω (Fig. 5b) [109], which can decelerate the Volmer reaction. In addition, the thermoneutral interaction of proton with the surface (ΔG H ≅ 0) can benefit the adsorption of hydrogen. As reported by Tsai et al. [115], the values of ΔG H were 0.06 eV on the Mo-edge, −0.45 eV on S-edge, and 1.92 eV on the basal plane, meaning that the edge sites have proper adsorption and desorption capacities of hydrogen intermediates simultaneously. The conductivity of MoS2 can be characterized by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). For example, Zang et al. [109] synthesized MoS2 with outstanding hydrogen evolution properties by carbon-induced orientation modulation, which can optimize the electronic and coordination structures of molybdenum disulfide. As shown in Fig. 5(b), Nyquist plots suggest that carbon doping in MoS2 could increase the interfacial electron-transfer kinetics. The EIS Nyquist plots could also provide the charge transfer resistance (R ct) of the catalyst, the uncompensated ohmic resistance of the electrochemical measurement system, and the ionic resistance of the electrolyte (R s). The constant-phase element (CPE) in the equivalent circuit model (inset in Fig. 5b) is used to fit impedance data. Regarding hydrogen evolution reaction, smaller R ct of the catalyst means faster electron transfer in Volmer reaction [116]. For semiconductors, the Mott-Schottky plot can be used for extracting the conduction and valence band positions of the semiconductive catalyst. The adsorption behavior of protons can also be determined by the θH (coverage of H) and ΔG H. θH represents the fraction of molybdenum or chalcogen atoms on the edge or basal plane that enables hydrogen binding. Higher θH could offer more sites for adsorbing the protons. The values of ΔG H can be used to describe the rate of reaction [80]. Weak bonding between hydrogen and the catalyst leads to a low concentration of proton being adsorbed on the catalyst; while strong bonding may limit the rate of the desorption step because Had always occupies the active sites of the catalyst. Thus the thermoneutral (ΔG H ≅ 0) interaction between hydrogen and the surface on catalysts is desired [80]. As indicated by previous work [7], Pt showing high catalytic activity of HER occurs for ΔG H ≅ 0. However, the activity of MoS2 is limited due to the extremely high ΔG H (=1.92 eV) on the basal plane of MoS2. The theoretical calculations revealed that the ΔG H on the edge sites of MoS2 was more thermo-neutral (0.08 eV) [96,97]. Therefore, several synthesis strategies were used to expose the edge plane and adjust the electronic structure of the surface on MoS2 [48,62,109]. Tang et al. [47] synthesized an ultrathin MoS2/nitrogen-doped rGO (the reduced graphene oxide) nanocomposite which presented a more preferable ΔG H value of −0.052 eV compared with the MoS2 nanosheet (−0.201 eV), resulting in the fast hydrogen desorption. 3.2.2 Desorption step In the desorption step expressed by Eqs. (2) or (3), the HER through the Tafel reaction is determined by the number and intrinsic activity of the active sites of the catalyst [117–119]. As discussed above, the HER rate through the Heyrovsky reaction can be influenced by conductivity, ΔG H, θH, and the number and intrinsic activity of the active sites. In order to increase the catalytic HER rate, increasing the number of active sites and the intrinsic activity of each active site are the two possible methods [102,120]. The number of active sites can be related to catalyst loading on the given electrode and its total catalytic active surface area. The mass loading of nonprecious materials, such as MoS2, is not seriously concerned because of their low cost. Measuring the total specific surface area is a rational procedure for determining the number of catalytic active sites of non-noble metal catalysts [121,122] because the total number of active sites usually scales with the total catalyst active surface area. The geometrical specific surface area (GEO) of an electrode can hardly represent the surface area of materials with nanostructures. Nano-engineering of catalysts can change the area substantially, which can be obtained by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method for assessing the geometrical specific surface area. BET relies on the adsorption of probe molecules such as N2 at the catalyst surface, which is valid for testing heterogeneous and complicated materials. However, the BET measurement of the catalyst might overestimate the active surface area due to the adsorption of some inactive parts of the catalyst (Fig. 5c) [102], leading to a conservative estimation of the intrinsic activity. It should be noted that the realistic reaction area might be dramatically different from the geometrical area of the flat electrode (Fig. 5c). Then, electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) is employed to estimate the active surface area in the electrochemical reaction through cyclic voltammetry measurements [123]. Combining the intrinsic activity of each catalytic site and its related physical and chemical properties is a way to understand catalytic behavior. However, non-Faradaic current, mass transport limitation, and/or catalyst instability can affect the measurement results of intrinsic activity. Li et al. [103] synthesized the vertical MoS2 nanolayers by the guidance of FeS2 sites supported on carbon nitride (C3N4) substrate to increase both the BET specific surface area and ECSA. An interfacial MoS2-based catalyst with polypyrrole substrate synthesized by a layer-by-layer strategy showed a much larger ECSA [124]. One of the well-known tools for assessing intrinsic per-site activity is the average turnover frequency (TOF), which is calculated by the equation of T O F = I / ( 2 F n ) , where I represents the current (A) during liner sweep measurement, n represents the number of active sites (mol), and F represents the Faraday constant (C mol−1). The factor 1/2 arrives by taking into account that two electrons are required to form one hydrogen molecule in HER [123,125,126]. Xu et al. [25] increased the TOF for MoS2 from 0.06 s−1 at an overpotential of 0.187 V to 0.138 s−1 at an overpotential of 0.179 V by constructing metal-ion bridging (C,P)3N4-M (Ni2+, Co2+)-MoS2 heterostructure through the hydrothermal method. Shin et al. [125] synthesized an amorphous MoS2 catalyst on Au with 1.45 s−1 at an overpotential of 0.2 V by an atomic layer deposition method. 3.2.3 Release step In the release step, the H2 is released from the surface of the catalyst, which is mainly influenced by the surface wettability of the catalyst. Catalysts with a hydrophilic surface can induce rapid detachment of hydrogen bubbles, resulting in enhanced HER performance. Fig. 5(d and e) shows the models of hydrogen detachment. During hydrogen evolution, the catalysts' surfaces with different contact angles can influence the speed of hydrogen gas detachment. The large contact angle of the liquid and solid leads to bubbles of large size, as shown in Fig. 5(d). On the other hand, the gas bubble can hardly grow up and may detach rapidly from the surface of the catalyst within a small contact angle. Thus, the adhesive contact area of the H2 bubbles is small (Fig. 5e). Furthermore, a hydrophilic catalyst can achieve an efficient and long-term hydrogen evolution reaction on account of the electrode-electrolyte interface with fewer adsorbed gas bubbles. Hence, the contact angle measurement can be applied to studying the hydrogen release. In this regard, Jung et al. [106] studied the effect of wettability and improved the hydrogen detachment by the controlling wettability of the MoS2 surface. A fast gas detachment from the catalytic surface of MoS2 was realized by minimizing the receding contact angle, resulting in an overpotential reduction in the MoS2. Gao et al. [127] optimized the adsorption of water molecules on the MoS2 catalyst by modifying the surface from hydrophobic to hydrophilic by introducing Ni3B4 dopants. The Ni3B4-doped MoS2 demonstrated a superior hydrophilic surface to pure-MoS2 [128]. 3.2.4 Practical application Lower overpotential and higher stability of the electrocatalysts are highly desired in the practical application of hydrogen generation, which are obtained by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and galvanostatic/potentiostatic electrolysis or repetitive cyclic voltammetry (CV), respectively. The Nernst potential of the hydrogen evolution reaction referenced to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) is zero at 100 kPa and 298 K. But some adverse issues such as poor energy efficiency and high activation energy lead to high kinetic barriers. An extra applied potential to overcome the overpotential is required for the practical HER process. Meanwhile, the internal resistance of the catalyst cannot be ignored, which originates from the contact resistance of the electrochemical system and the intrinsic resistances of the electrocatalyst and electrolyte. Thus, the potential (E) necessary to drive HER is can be expressed by E = E H E R + i R + η , where E HER represents the Nernst potential, i is the current density, and R is the ohmic resistance when current flows across the electrochemical system. Usually, the overpotential at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 (per geometric area of an electrode), η 10 , is a widely used indicator to compare the activities of various catalysts in HER, corresponding to ∼10% solar-to-chemicals efficiency of HER [129]. η 10 value can estimate the activity of a catalyst faithfully with the same mass loading of the material on the electrode with the same geometrical area. Electrochemical stability is another important parameter for the practical application of HER. To evaluate the electrochemical durability of a catalyst, two electrocatalytic approaches for the stability measurements have been proposed: galvanostatic electrolysis (or potentiostatic electrolysis) and cyclic voltammetry. The potentiostatic (or galvanostatic) method is to monitor the current density (or potential) variation with reaction time at a constant overpotential (or current density). High stability is represented by the longer duration without or only with slight current density (or potential) change. The catalytic test should be lasted for at least 10 h under an applied current density of at least 10 mA cm−2. The repetitive CV method is first conducted in a certain cycling run (e.g., 10,000 runs) and then compared to find the difference in overpotentials before and after the CV. A small decrease in the overpotential suggests the high durability of the electrocatalyst [130]. The stability of most MoS2-based catalysts was only characterized for 24 h [82,98], which is far more from the practical application. The catalyst for industrial hydrogen production works for decades, which makes an enormous challenge for the stability of MoS2 electrocatalysts [131]. According to the proposed mechanism, the high-efficiency green production of H2 from electrocatalytic water splitting requires electrical conductivity, an abundant number of active sites, good surface wettability, and ΔG H. The large-scale manufacture of hydrogen energy demands high-efficiency, low-cost, and stable catalysts. The manipulation of the catalytic performance of MoS2 by active surface/interface engineering plays a significant role in hydrogen mass production. 4 Active surface/interface engineering in molybdenum disulfide Various strategies have been developed for enhancing the electrocatalytic performances by engineering the MoS2-based materials, such as phase engineering [132–137], defect engineering [119,138], morphology design [139,140], and heterostructure construction [112,141–143]. These strategies can provide various paths for optimizing the key factors which limit the electrocatalytic performances, i.e., the density of catalytic active sites, the electrical conductivity, the adsorption free energy of the reaction intermediates, and the surface wettability as mentioned in Section 2 in this review [80]. The types, optimizing strategies, and HER performance of the reported MoS2 based catalysts in recent literature were summarized in Table 1 . Tuning the contents of different phases in MoS2 could achieve enhancements in electrical conductivity because the metallic 1T-phased MoS2 could provide faster electron transfer for accelerating electrocatalytic reactions compared with the semiconducting 2H-phased MoS2 with a large bandgap. The intrinsic defects and the dopant-induced defects have shown profound impacts on catalytic performance as explained by structural-induced effect and electronic effect. Nanoscale catalysts with large surface areas and specific morphologies could efficiently boost the HER performance on account of the exposure of active crystal facets and abundant active sites, as well as fast mass transportation. Besides, constructing heterostructures can also provide abundant interfaces between the different components and optimize the electronic configuration by affecting the interfacial electron transfer, which optimizes ΔG H and simultaneously improves electrochemical activity, facilitating the overall HER process. 4.1 Phase engineering The crystal structure can show a strong influence on the physicochemical properties in electrocatalytic reactions [196], thermocatalytic reactions [197], and photocatalytic reactions [198,199]. Compared with 2H-MoS2, 1T-MoS2 possesses a modified structure and high active basal planes. Thus, the electrochemical performance could be promoted by increasing the content of metastable and active 1T-MoS2. The natural phase of 2H-MoS2 is thermodynamically stable, while the metastable 1T-MoS2 can only be obtained under harsh synthetic conditions, including the bottom-up synthesis through the hydrothermal/solvothermal reaction [200], confined template method [94], and colloidal synthesis [201], as well as the top-down synthesis through the lithium [90] or alkali metal intercalation-exfoliation [202], electron-beam irradiation [137], plasma hot-electron transfer [133,203], and mechanical strain [99]. The bottom-up methods, such as hydrothermal/solvothermal reactions, can be used for synthesizing 1T-MoS2 with reaction solvent molecules and precursor ions. While the growth kinetics are similar for these methods. The bottom-up methods can produce a few-layered 1T-MoS2 and 1T-MoS2 with specific morphologies (nanosheets, nanoparticles, etc.) by controlling the growth kinetics. Chen et al. [94] directly synthesized high-purity 1T-MoS2 with a 1T content of 83% using a hydrothermal method through a spatially confined template of layered Ni(OH)2, as demonstrated in Fig. 6 (a). The spherical aberration-corrected transmission electron microscopy (CS-TEM) observation indicates the close-coupling between the MoS2 flakes and NiS2 layers (Fig. 6b and c). The scanning transmission electron microscope high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF-STEM) image and its simulation (Fig. 6d and e) indicate that the MoS2 phase is a 1T-MoS2 crystal structure with an octahedral coordination atomic structure. The crystal phase of MoS2 can be also observed by the atomic arrangement of two S atoms between neighboring Mo atoms, as shown in Fig. 6(f). The 1T-MoS2/NiS2 catalyst exhibits a lower overpotential (116 mV at 10 mA cm−2) than that of the 2H-MoS2/NiS2 counterpart (Fig. 6g). This study revealed that the crystal phase control strategy for MoS2 nanomaterials can be achieved by using confining templates. Huang et al. [200] synthesized a metallic 1T-MoS2 with atomically engineered metal doping sites using Anderson-type polyoxometalates ([XH6Mo6O24] n −) as the precursors. The procedure for synthesizing XO@1T-MoS2 on carbon fiber paper with XMo6 through a hydrothermal reaction is shown in Fig. 6(h). The HAADF-STEM images in Fig. 6(i) show the structure of 1T-MoS2 is thin layers. The atomic arrangement of 1T-MoS2 is shown in the aberration-corrected atomic resolution HAADF-STEM image (Fig. 6j). The as-synthesized NiO@1T-MoS2 exhibited a low overpotential of 46 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in alkaline electrolyte. Combining the bottom-up methods with morphology design, Zhang et al. [145] prepared 1T-MoS2 by synthesizing 1T-MoS2 nanosheets embedded on black TiO2− x nanotube arrays grown on Ti plate (1T-MoS2/TiO2 − x @Ti) (Fig. 7 a). The TEM image in Fig. 7(b) demonstrates that ultrathin nanosheets are embedded in the TiO2− x nanotubes. The layered structure has lattice fringe spacings of 0.68 and 0.27 nm as shown in Fig. 7(c), which correspond to the (0 0 2) plane of 2H-MoS2 and (1 0 1) plane of 1T-MoS2. The inset in Fig. 7(c) shows the octahedral coordination of 1T-MoS2. The HRTEM in Fig. 7(d) exhibits that the interlayer spacing of 0.35 nm on the nanotube substrate corresponds to anatase TiO2. 1T-MoS2/TiO2− x @Ti shows the high activity of HER with a small overpotential (146 mV at 10 cm−2) and a small Tafel slope (42 mV dec−1), as shown in Fig. 7(e and f), because the ultrathin 1T-MoS2 nanosheets anchor on the TiO2− x nanotube arrays. The top-down methods usually intercalate various foreign Lewis bases and alkali-metal ions into the MoS2 interlayers to form 1T-MoS2. Compared with hydrothermal/solvothermal reactions, the top-down methods can achieve large-scale production of 1T phase MoS2. The ion intercalation can induce a conversion from 2H-phase to 1T-phase MoS2 by enlarging the interlayer spacing and changing the crystal structure of the MoS2 host lattice [90]. Wang et al. [146] synthesized an ultra-stable in-plane 1T-2H MoS2 heterostructure by introducing strain with phosphorus atoms, which could be stored for 500 days at room temperature. These heterostructures were obtained through the annealing treatment of 2H-MoS2 bulk under a mixture gas of phosphorous vapor and Ar (Fig. 8 a). The phosphorus can occupy the interspace of the interlayers in MoS2 to expand the lattice and embed it into the MoS2 bulk lattice to induce the partial phase transition from 2H– to 1T- MoS2. HRTEM images in Fig. 8(b and c) show the lattice fringes of 1T and 2H phases, and defects and deformation resulting from the inserted phosphorus atoms into MoS2. Remarkably, two distinct lattice regions with a similar crystalline space (~0.27 nm) are shown in a plane: the hexagonal lattice region contains (1 0 0) and (0 1 0) planes of 2H MoS2, and the trigonal lattice region involves the (1 0 1) plane of 1T MoS2. The improved HER performance shown in Fig. 8(d and e) demonstrates that the in-plane 1T-2H MoS2 heterostructure possesses a lower overpotential (245 mV at 10 mA cm−2) and higher electrical conductivity of 8620 S m−1, which is more suitable for HER than 2H-MoS2 bulk and 2H-MoS2 nanosheets. High electrical conductivity and electrocatalytic activity on basal planes of 1T-MoS2 develop the potential of molybdenum disulfide for fast HER. Bottom-up methods can produce 1T-MoS2 with high morphology quality but are limited by the yield. Thus these methods are mainly used for basic research. Top-down processes are cost-efficiency and suitable for mass production of 1T-MoS2. The synthesis of MoS2 with large content of 1T phase could achieve high activity towards HER because of the additional active basal planes. Furthermore, combining the 1T-MoS2 nanosheets with other materials [196] and accurately controlling the synthesis of 1T-MoS2 nanosheets [132] can deliver novel interfacial catalysts with a unique 1T-phase structure, leading to a fast Volmer reaction in HER. 4.2 Defect engineering Defects exist in all catalysts, which obey the second law of thermodynamics [204] and can be categorized into surface defects and bulk defects by their different positions. Defects show a deviation of the normal lattice in the nodes or adjacent regions [205]. These defects are usually thermodynamically unstable but quite effective and are most commonly used in the electrocatalytic process [206]. Through designing the surface defects, the electron density, electrical conductivity, coordination environment, interaction with surroundings, molecule adsorption/desorption energy, and energy bandgap of MoS2 can be modified for fast HER [207,208]. According to the origins of surface defects, they can be classified as doping-induced defects and intrinsic defects. An intrinsic defect occurs when atoms lose in the lattice node, while the doping-induced defect is the replacement of normal atoms or the occupation of gap positions in the normal lattice node by inducing heteroatoms, as shown in Fig. 9 . Generally, the classifications of defects are becoming more complicated and diversiform as knowledge of the theoretical and experimental expands. These defects can cause a redistribution of the electronic structure of the nanomaterials by disturbing or even breaking the periodic structure of crystals, providing ways to optimize the electrocatalytic performance by means of altering the contents, locations, and/or species of defects [209,210]. In recent years, the advanced research on defects design of MoS2-based materials has been reviewed as shown in Fig. 10 , which revealed that the defects can optimize electronic configuration and modulate their surface/interface microenvironments, enhancing their electrocatalytic performance [162,211–215]. 4.2.1 Intrinsic defects The introduction of intrinsic defects can produce high-density dangling bonds and unsaturated atoms and expose more active sites in the thermodynamically stable (0 0 2) planes of the MoS2 nanosheets [162]. The concentration and distribution of vacancies are the major factors influencing intrinsic defects. Xie et al. [162] used precursors to react with different amounts of thiourea for investigating the influence of vacancy concentration on catalysis. The reaction could control the defect generation in MoS2 ultrathin nanosheets. This strategy was a scalable path to introduce engineering defects into MoS2 surface to create partial cracking of the basal planes (Fig. 11 a) to expose active edge sites. The ultrathin nanosheet morphology is clearly shown in the TEM image (Fig. 11b). Many distortions and dislocations can also be observed in the (1 0 0) basal plane and (0 0 2) edge plane, as shown in the HRTEM images at the top (Fig. 11c) and side view (Fig. 11d), respectively. The disordered atom arrangement can cause the cracking of the basal planes and thus form additional edges. With the intrinsic defect-induced engineering, the defect-rich MoS2 nanosheets show outstanding HER performances with a small onset overpotential in Fig. 11(e) (193 mV at 10 mA cm−2). Wang et al. [216] investigated the impact of vacancy states on catalysis in addition to concentration via high throughput calculations. They developed a uniformly single S vacancy tailoring strategy by a mild H2O2 chemical etch on the basal plane (Fig. 11f). The spacing of typical crystal lattices increases from 0.64 to 0.68 nm after 60 s H2O2 etching (Fig. 11g and h). Fig. 11(i) exhibits few agglomerated S-vacancies and homogeneous distribution of single S-vacancies on the surface, while Fig. 11(j) indicates both the top and side views of a representative model. The optimal S-vacancy state is created on the MoS2 surface when the H2O2 etching duration is 60 s, resulting in a small η at 10 mA cm−2 (131 mV), as shown in Fig. 11(k). Intrinsic defects in the MoS2 lattice can deviate from the fixed molecular stoichiometries and tune the neighboring atomic and electronic arrangements [217,218]. The introduction of vacancy is an effective electronic structure engineering. This strategy can achieve high exposure of the catalytic edge active sites, activating the basal planes and intrinsic conductivity enhancement [219,220]. The intrinsic defect engineering can be extended to defect engineering to a more sophisticated level, thus further uncovering the potential of electrocatalytic HER performance enhancement. 4.2.2 Doping-induced defects The doping-induced defects can optimize the catalytic properties via integrating the unique 2D geometric structure with doping-induced electronic structure modulation on the basal plane. MoS2 nanosheets can support and stabilize the dopant with the crystallographic arrangement or the coordination environment of strong covalent bonds, but the doping atoms remain coordinately unsaturated, providing the active sites for catalysis reaction. Besides, the catalytic HER activity of the active sites on the MoS2 can be improved by the formation of new electronic states, resulting from the strong electronic interaction between the doping-induced defects and the MoS2 host. As reported, the MoS2 edges had metallic states while the basal plane of MoS2 nanosheets is semiconducting [221]. Enhancing the conductivity of the semiconducting basal plane is critical in promoting electrocatalytic HER activity. To enhance the conductivity of MoS2, Mo atoms in MoS2 could be replaced by a series of doping metals (Pt, V, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Mn, etc.) [175,222–226]. For example, Bolar et al. [165] prepared a vanadium-doped MoS2 (VMS) through a colloquial solvothermal method. As shown in Fig. 12 (a and b), when the electrode is in contact with the electrolyte, the Fermi level of VMS moves towards the conduction band, resulting in a band bending of the electrode. The junction is in flat potential when the band bending is absent in the junction between electrolyte and electrode at a certain applied potential. (Fig. 12c) Mott-Schottky plot in Fig. 12(d and e) exhibits the flat band potential of MoS2 changed with V-doping, leading to a fast charge transfer property at the interfaces. As a result, the low overpotentials of 206 and 194 mV at 10 mA cm−2 are obtained in basic and acidic media, respectively (Fig. 12f and g). However, inserting metal dopants with large atomic sizes, such as V, Fe, Co, and Ni, into the MoS2 matrix is technically challenging [227]. Metal atoms dopant in the basal plane of MoS2 may cause the undesirable growth of MoS3 or promotion on the terrace sites, resulting in instability of the MoS2 structure [223,228]. Zhang et al. [166] boosted catalytic HER activity through surface modulation at the atomic level, ruling out the affection of structural phase transitions. As shown in Fig. 12(h), the basal plane of MoS2 is decorated by the isolated Ni atom, which is supported on multichannel carbon nanofiber. The field-emission scanning electron (FESEM) image in Fig. 12(i) exhibits the randomly assembled nanosheets of the MoS2 shell. The extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) results (Fig. 12j) show a dominant peak located at 1.63 Å which can be ascribed to the Ni–S bonding. No Ni–Ni bonding exists in MCM@MoS2, evidencing the absence of Ni clusters and particles. Compared with pristine MoS2 (297 mV) and MCM@MoS2 (263 mV), the overpotential of MCM@MoS2-Ni demonstrates a positive shift at 10 mA cm−2 (161 mV), as shown in Fig. 12(k). Besides, the Tafel slopes of pristine MoS2, MCM@MoS2, and MCM@MoS2-Ni in Fig. 12(l) are 81, 136, and 179 mV dec−1, respectively, indicating that the single-atom surface modification can accelerate HER kinetics. Li et al. [229] synthesized Co-doped MoS2 (Co-MoS2) with rich defects and edges through an in-situ sulphuration method (Fig. 13 a). The morphology of Co-doped MoS2 is a nanoscale particulate with abundant MoS2 layers, as shown in Fig. 13(b). Fig. 13(c) exhibits the structure of Co-doped MoS2 with short-range crystallinity, which originates from the spatial confinement effect of the retained carbon substrate. The lattice fringe (0.66 nm) in Fig. 13(d) corresponds to the MoS2. The lattice distortion and Co atom dopants in Co-doped MoS2 benefit electrocatalysis. The introduction of atomic Co into MoS2 gives rise to outstanding HER overpotentials in both alkaline (67 mV at 10.0 mA cm−2 in Fig. 13e) and acid (155 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in Fig. 13f) electrolytes. The ΔG H absolute values of edged Mo sites, edged S sites, and basal S sites in MoS2 decrease with the introduction of Co atoms (Fig. 13g), which indicates the doping effect could optimize the ΔG H and adjust the adsorption and desorption of HER. A deeper understanding of the promotional effect can benefit the development of HER electrocatalysts. The introduction of cation could activate the inert S atoms in the basal plane. Single-atom modification can provide a way to investigate the atomic coordination environment of the single heteroatom at the atomic level. Apart from the cation doping strategy, the replacement of S atoms with small atomic size nonmetal elements (N, O, Se, P, etc.) has been considered the feasible solution to accelerate the sluggish charge transfer [119,168–171,230,231]. For example, Xiao et al. [119] synthesized N-doped MoS2 nanosheets by a facile and cost-effective one-step sintering method. The thin nanosheets have clear edges in SEM images (Fig. 14 a and b). The typical 2D lamellar morphology of MoS2 offers some exposed edges which are active for HER. Besides, the deconvolution of MoS2 sheets could provide a large surface area that supports the hydrogen generation process. Fig. 14(c and d) demonstrates the less aggregation of MoS2 with only 2–4 layers. They also revealed that the N dopants in the MoS2 catalyst could activate HER activity and accelerate the charge transfer in the MoS2 basal plane, leading to a small overpotential (121 mV at 100 mA cm−2) (Fig. 14e). To further prove that the N substitution on S site (NS) dopants could activate the activity, they investigated the hydrogen absorption effect of NS in the Mo-edge and inert S-edge to tune the ΔG H. As shown in Fig. 14(f and g), the ΔG H values of pristine Mo-edge, S-edge, and basal plane change from −0.34, and −0.71 eV to −0.19, and 0.06 eV after N doping, respectively, which is conducive to HER process. The change of ΔG H values indicates that NS dopant could activate the HER activity of inert S-edge and Mo-edge. A novel strategy except single element doping, the intercalation of N plus PO4 3− was also used to produce a high proportion (ca. 41%) of 1T-MoS2 in 2H-MoS2, as reported by Deng et al. [232] 10% of single PO4 3− intercalation or ca. 28% of single N doping was obtained. The designed (N, PO4 3−)-MoS2 in Fig. 14(h) are combined with conductive substrate, the vertical graphene (VG) skeleton, to form binder-free arrays for further enhancing HER kinetics. The transformation from 2H-phase to 1T-phase is demonstrated in HAADF images of Fig. 14(i and j). Note that the (N, PO4 3−)-MoS2/VG remains the three-dimensional (3D) porous array architecture (Fig. 14k), suggesting good structure stability of the nanosheet. Owing to the doped effect and the control of phase, the designed (N, PO4 3−)-MoS2/VG electrocatalyst demonstrates an excellent HER performance, as shown in Fig. 14(l and m) (overpotential of 85 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and Tafel slope of 42 mV dec−1). The anion dopants can accelerate change transfer to enhance the electrocatalytic HER activity of the S-edge of MoS2 and improve the electrical conductivity of the basal plane of MoS2. Besides, the doped elements or intercalated ions can also achieve controllable phase transformation (1T-MoS2 from 2H-MoS2), boosting the change transfer within the MoS2. Defects, including vacancy and the doped exotic atoms, can affect the neighboring electronic structure and surface/interface property of MoS2-based catalyst by disrupting the original charge balance and creating a new distribution of charge, which then regulates the ΔG H and improves the conductivity of MoS2 [71]. Specifically, some defects on both edge and basal planes in MoS2 can also serve as active centers, providing unsaturated atoms for efficient HER [209]. However, controllable defect construction with specific types is challenging because of the complexity of defects in MoS2. In this sense, more accurate defect introduction methods are required to be further explored. 4.3 Morphology design The delicate design of morphology can simultaneously give both high electronic conductivity and large specific active surface areas of MoS2 nanosheets. Many morphological design methods have been developed to synthesize MoS2-based materials with various shapes and sizes as well as large active surface areas, such as vertical structure [25,180,181] and yolk-shell structure [139,182]. The formation of nanostructure with specific morphology can not only expose more catalytic active sites on the larger specific area of MoS2 but also provide many pathways for fast ion/charge transfer between layers of MoS2. The electrical conductivity along the layer was about 2200 times higher than that across the layers in the material [80]. Ge et al. [181] synthesized an electrocatalyst assembled by vertical growth MoS2 on the reduced graphene oxide (RGO) via the link of transition metal ions as bridges, as shown in Fig. 15 (a). The introduction of bridging metal ions can inhibit the agglomeration of MoS2 nanosheets as well as the restack and enfoldment of RGO nanosheets (Fig. 15b and c), resulting in MoS2 sheets grown uniformly and vertically on RGO. The metal ions can not only cling to the molybdate precursor with a negative charge, being the nucleation centers for MoS2 nanosheets and synthesizing highly dispersed nanosheets, but also bond with the O in RGO surface and Mo in MoS2 nanosheets as the fast channels for electron transfer between graphene substrate and MoS2 nanosheets, resulting in higher conductivity of the electrocatalysis. Thus, a low overpotential (198 mV at 10 mA cm−2) is obtained as shown in Fig. 15(d). Xu et al. [25] synthesized MoS2 nanosheets growing perpendicularly on the P-doped carbon nitride ((C,P)3N4) nanolayer under the assistance of Ni2+ and Co3+ metal-ion bridges, forming a high-quality (C,P)3N4-M (Ni2+, Co2+)-MoS2 electrocatalyst for HER, as shown in Fig. 15(e). Ni2+-and Co2+-assisted growth could remarkably increase charge transfer through the short-distance channels between (C,P)3N4 and MoS2 and enhance the exposure of the active site on account of less stack and more edge exposure of MoS2 (Fig. 15f). Furthermore, the basal plane of the carbon nitride substrate became more conductive with P doping. These strategies achieved charge transfer optimization, (C,P)3N4-M (Ni2+, Co2+)-MoS2 exhibited low overpotential (179 mV at 10 mA cm−2) in an acid medium (Fig. 15g). As identified, a high conductive substrate is desirable for constructing efficient vertical electrocatalysts. Vertical ultrathin MoS2 nanosheet arrays were grown on hydrogenated graphene (HG), as reported by Han et al. [180] (Fig. 15h). The wrinkled MoS2 nanosheets are vertically oriented without agglomeration, as shown in Fig. 15(i) and its insert. The expanded lattice space of 0.65 nm in Fig. 15(j) is corresponding to the (002) plane of MoS2, which confirms the interaction between MoS2 and HG. Fig. 15(k) shows the low overpotential of 124 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a small Tafel slope of 41 mV dec−1. These outstanding HER properties have resulted from the synergistic effects among high conductivity, large surface area, more active sites, and reduced Had energy by specific perpendicular structure. The morphological design can also be combined with defect engineering to accelerate the catalytic HER process [233–235]. Dong et al. [234] synthesized hierarchical composite catalysts for HER, in which the nitrogen (N)-doped carbon nanotubes (CNTs) were decorated with Ni atoms-incorporated vertical MoS2 nanosheets. The incorporation of Ni atoms could induce abundant unsaturated S atoms on the basal plane, leading to intensive active site exposure. Meanwhile, the substrate of N-doped CNTs can guide the growth of MoS2 nanosheets and heighten the conductivity of the electrocatalyst. Based on the increased active sites and the enhanced conductivity, the hierarchical electrocatalyst exhibited low overpotentials (158 and 179 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1.0 M KOH, respectively), small Tafel slopes (62.3 and 69.3 mV dec−1 in the alkaline and acidic solutions, respectively) and long-time durability in both acidic and alkaline electrolytes. Experimental and theoretical investigations have indicated that morphology design strategy can increase micro- and nano-scale roughness of MoS2-based catalysts, which is crucial for the mass transfer and gas release on the interface between MoS2 and electrolyte. In addition, the enhanced active site exposure originating from morphology design can lead to high catalytic HER activity. Owing to the rapid gas release and the increased active site exposure, controlling morphology can achieve fast kinetics of both hydrogen absorption/desorption processes as well as H2 gas release. However, morphology design and optimization of MoS2 can hardly boost intrinsic activity and accelerate electron transfer in the basal plane. The other interface/surface engineering methods need to be combined to improve the overall catalytic HER activity and conductivity. 4.4 Heterostructure construction Heterostructures possess superior electrochemical properties in comparison with their corresponding single components owing to the synergistic effect on interfaces. Abundant interfaces between the different components can be induced into hybrid catalyst and optimize the electronic configuration by affecting the interfacial electron configuration [236,237]. The design and synthesis of the MoS2-based hybrids could be a viable way to accelerate the sluggish HER kinetics. Constructing heterostructure can also optimize ΔG H and simultaneously improve electrochemical activity, facilitating the overall HER process [141]. The synergistic effect of different components in MoS2-based electrocatalysts can unlock abundant possibilities for the modulation of HER performances. The heterostructures can be made with molybdenum-based compounds, sulfides, etc. For example, Zhang et al. [185] developed an exfoliation technique followed by thermal treatment and produced an HC-MoS2/Mo2C heterostructure (Fig. 16 a). The 2D MoS2 flakes without clear defects in their edge and basal planes are shown in Fig. 16(b). The α-Mo2C is formed on 2D MoS2 flakes after the thermal treatment (Fig. 16c). HC-MoS2/Mo2C delivers an overpotential of 412 mV at 1000 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 60 mV dec−1 for HER via combining the merits of MoS2 and Mo2C (Fig. 16d and e). Feng et al. [112] combined phase control and heterostructure construction to synthesize a 3D 1T-MoS2/CoS2 heterostructure through an in-situ self-growing strategy (Fig. 16f). Comparing with SEM images at various resolutions (Fig. 16g) of molybdate cobalt oxide, 1T-MoS2/CoS2 with calcination of thiourea shows the 1D nanorods decorated with abundant flexible nanosheets (Fig. 16h). The microstructure of the 3D 1T-MoS2/CoS2 heterostructure can be seen by TEM and HRTEM images (Fig. 16h and i). The (2 0 0) plane of CoS2 and the (0 0 2) plane of MoS2 can join together, indicating the vertical growth of MoS2 nanosheets on the CoS2 nanosheets. The highly exposed edge planes of the ultrathin MoS2 nanosheets (3–6 layers in Fig. 16j) can provide abundant active sites for high catalytic HER process. Notably, the hexagonal lattice of 2H-phase and trigonal lattice of 1T-phase coexist in a plane (Fig. 16k). This 3D heterostructure with a high content of 76.6% for 1T-MoS2, and the abundant interfaces between CoS2 and MoS2 nanosheets can effectively increase the catalytic active site exposure. Therefore, the obtained 3D 1T-MoS2/CoS2 possesses outstanding electrocatalytic HER activity in both acid and alkaline electrolytes (Fig. 16l and m). HER in the alkaline electrode is kinetically retarded on account of the slow water dissociation process. The kinetics of alkaline HER can be accelerated by combining MoS2 and components as an OH− acceptor. For example, Zhang et al. [141] synthesized a Ni(OH)2/MoS2 heterostructure with outstanding alkaline HER activity, resulting from the synergistic effect of Ni(OH)2 and MoS2 on their interface. The Ni(OH)2 could promote water dissociation and hydrogen intermediate production as well as the nearby MoS2 with active sites which could adsorb hydrogen intermediates and product hydrogen molecule, as illustrated in Fig. 17 (a). The TEM image in Fig. 17(b) confirms that Ni(OH)2 nanoparticles are dispersed on the surface of MoS2, generating abundant interfaces for hydrogen evolution reactions. The interlayer distance ascribed to the (0 0 2) plane of MoS2 slightly increases after the Ni(OH)2 is deposited (Fig. 17c and d). The typical lamellar heterostructure of Ni(OH)2/MoS2@CC has a low HER overpotential of 80 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 17e) with a Tafel slope of 60 mV dec−1 (Fig. 17f). Hu et al. [186] dramatically improved the HER kinetics by constructing vertical MoS2 sheets with NiCo-based layered double hydroxide (NiCo-LDH), as shown in Fig. 17(g). The TEM image in Fig. 17(h) demonstrates the lattice fringes of 0.21, 0.26, and 0.62, which agree with the (015) and (012) lattice spacing of NiCo-LDH, as well as (002) lattice spacing of MoS2, respectively. The judicious hybridization of MoS2 and LDH (insert in Fig. 17h) can speed up water dissociation steps in alkaline HER by decreasing the activation energies of MoS2/NiCo-LDH (Fig. 17i). The lower overpotential of MoS2/NiCo-LDH heterostructure in Fig. 17(j) also confirms that the hybridization can enhance the HER activity of electrocatalyst. Wei et al. [187] developed an approach that combines heterostructure construction with morphology design. They synthesized the MoS2 arrays onto the NiCo-LDH template deposited on the carbon cloth substrate, which oriented the growth of molybdenum disulfide nanosheets. The template of NiCo-LDH enables the epitaxy of MoS2 and the large exposure of active sites. Thus, the electrode only requires a small overpotential (153 mV) at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte. Besides, heterostructure construction strategy can also activate the basal planes of MoS2. Kim et al. [76] developed a method to activate the basal planes of MoS2 through growing Ni2P nanoparticles on basal planes of MoS2. The Ni2P/MoS2 heterostructure with a substrate of N-doped carbon nanotube (Ni2P/MoS2/N:CNT, as shown in Fig. 18 a) achieves HER performance enhancement. The Ni2P/MoS2/N:CNT heterostructure exhibits an HER activity and outperforms the Pt/C electrocatalyst in the high current density region (>200 mA cm−2), as shown in Fig. 18(b). The small Tafel slope of Ni2P/MoS2/N:CNT shown in Fig. 18(c) shows that the mechanism is in agreement with the Volmer-Heyrovsky-release process. MoS2 demonstrates fast adsorption of Had when constructing heterostructure with other components such as metal oxides and hydroxides, which could be effective for cleaving the HO–H bond in both neutral and alkaline media [238–240], thus facilitating the overall catalytic HER process. The flexible modulation of composite interfaces for better HER performances can be achieved by the precise design of the component and dispersion corresponding heterostructure [37]. The interface effect in heterostructure hastens the slow Volmer reaction, thus leading to a Volmer step followed by a Heyrovsky mechanism with fast reaction kinetics. This is because the interface modification can decrease the energy barrier of hydrogen adsorption steps, thus enhancing the electrical activity of active sites. 5 Challenges of MoS2-based electrocatalysts MoS2-based catalysts possess catalytic HER activity and have been widely regarded as the substitute for noble metal catalysts. This is owing to their layered crystal structure and specific electronic structure. The active edge Mo and S sites of 2H-MoS2 have the ΔG H values close to neutral, which are favorable for electrocatalysis. The cost-effective MoS2 with earth-abundant elements of Mo and S is promising for practical application. Although achievements and advantages of MoS2-based electrocatalysts have been made till now, MoS2-based electrocatalysts for commercial hydrogen generation are still requiring further modification and manipulation to meet the requirements of practical application. Each modification strategy mentioned above has its bottlenecks, which limit the catalytic HER performance. The 1T-MoS2 possesses outstanding electronic conductivity, active basal plane, and hydrophilic surface, which is favorable for electrocatalytic hydrogen production. But, the research on 1T-MoS2 still suffers from worse phase stability. The content of the 1T-phase is mainly in a range of 40 wt% to 83 wt% in 2H-MoS2 [94,241]. The poor stability and low purity limit the exploration of the full potential of 1T-MoS2 in electrocatalytic reactions. Furthermore, the conventional exfoliated methods have low output and harsh preparation conditions. Thus, stability, large-yield, simple synthetic methods with high purity of metallic 1T-phase MoS2 should be further improved. The defects engineering could optimize electronic configuration and modulate surface/interface microenvironments of MoS2-based electrocatalysts. In the case of catalytic HER, defect introduction could simultaneously achieve conductivity improvement, activity increase, and ΔG H optimization in the basal plane. However, more controllable and accurate methods for defects introduction still need to be explored. Quantitative defect construction with specific types is difficult because of the complexity of defects in MoS2. Furthermore, the dynamic evolution of defect structures with high reactivity and high energy usually occur in the catalytic process, which plays a vital role in catalytic HER activity. The effects of defects’ dynamic evolution and the relationship between defect structures with the electrocatalytic property need to be investigated and clarified by in-situ characterization. As for morphology design, the formation of nanostructures with specific shapes and sizes could expose more catalytic active sites of the larger specific areas of MoS2 and also provide many pathways for fast ion/charge transfer in interfaces. However, the specific morphology of MoS2 could hardly increase the intrinsic activity of the active site and change electron transfer in the basal plane, which limits the overall activity and conductivity. In addition, the MoS2-based electrocatalysts with specific morphologies usually possess poorer stability than bulk or agglomerated MoS2. For heterostructure construction, the additional parts could confine and guide the growth of MoS2 for a well-dispersed structure and expose abundant active sites, such as MoS2/Co(OH)2 heterostructure. Though Co(OH)2 has little effect on ΔG H and the number and activity of edge active sites, the interfaces possess favorable ΔG H and can act as new highly tunable and active catalytic sites [117]. Furthermore, the interfaces in heterostructure can optimize the electronic configuration by means of affecting the interfacial electron transfer and improving the conductivity among semiconducting 2H phase MoS2 and the additional components. The great challenge of constructing heterostructure is how to combine MoS2 with other materials to achieve unusual chemical and physical properties which are not observed on the original single layers. 6 Summary and outlook The possible mechanisms of HER catalyzed by MoS2-based catalysts have been reviewed in this paper. Three steps of hydrogen production, including the adsorption step, desorption step, and release step have been discussed. The adsorption step and the Heyrovsky reaction are primarily affected by the conductivity, ΔG H value, and the active sites. The Tafel reaction is mainly influenced by ΔG H and the active sites. The wettability is a key factor affecting the release step. The researches of mechanisms reveal the factors that influence the hydrogen generation process, which could guide the synthesis of the promising MoS2-based electrocatalysts with high electrical conductivity, near-zero adsorption free energy of intermediates, a large number of active sites, and the super hydrophilic surface. We have attempted to provide an overview of recently developed surface and interface engineering methods for synthesizing high-active MoS2-based catalysts including the control of crystal structures, manufacturing defects, designing specific morphologies, and constructing heterostructures. Different phases of MoS2 with different structures exhibit excellent performance for different purposes; i.e., 1T-MoS2 shows favorable electrocatalytic activity because its metallic property is desirable for charger transfer while 2H-MoS2 is more suitable for photocatalysis with a direct bandgap. The metallic phase (1T-MoS2) possesses outstanding conductivity, which can accelerate the Volmer step in HER. However, phase engineering such as preparing a perfect crystal structure is not enough for a high-efficiency electrocatalyst. Benefited from the development of defect engineering, doping heteroatoms and intrinsic defects on the surface of MoS2 show another way of developing high-activity HER catalysts. Surface/interface engineering of the catalysts by the introduction of defects can prominently modulate the electronic structure, Mo/S atom local bonding environment, and the band structure of MoS2, and thus boost the charge transfer ability. Besides, introducing the substrates coupling with MoS2 to form artificial morphology could enhance the specific surface area and achieve high HER performance. Conductive substrates like carbon are feasible materials to increase the electronic conductivity and mass transfer of the catalysts. Morphological modification is a promising and intriguing way because higher conductivity and large active specific surface areas of MoS2 nanosheets can be achieved at the same time. Introducing other highly efficient materials for heterostructure construction can also benefit the HER. The flexible modulation of composite interfaces in heterostructure construction for better HER performance can be achieved by the delicate design of the corresponding part of the heterostructure. Novel MoS2-based materials with the precise control of electronic structure and morphology are still highly demanded. However, the majority of the modulating strategies for surface/interface engineering on the MoS2-based electrocatalysts require complicated multistep processes and costly structural and spectral characterizations, limiting the research of MoS2-based catalysts with well-engineered interfaces. Designing desirable catalysts through theoretical calculations is an instructive method. The calculated bond strengths of the reaction intermediates on the catalysts’ active sites could guide the electronic structure adjustment and the electrochemical HER optimization on the active sites. However, the research on rate-determining steps, simulating the energy transfer processes, and predicting the intermediate states are still needed to be further explored. Currently, many efforts are still on the way to achieving scalable and facile methods to synthesize catalysts for practical application. However, the large overpotential values and poor stability of HER catalyzed by MoS2-based materials are still far from applications in the industry. Developing MoS2-based catalysts with high stability and energy efficiency is largely dependent on the ingenious design and synthesis strategies in future electrocatalysis exploration. As the unremitting research of surface/interface engineering strategies and other strategies, novel MoS2-based electrocatalysts would be able to provide solutions for solving the obstacles in the way of their practical green energy applications. Lei, J. Zhan, L. Tang, Y. Zhang, Y. Wang, Adv. Energy Mater. 8 (2018) 1703482. Yao Xu got his BSc degree from Qingdao University of Science and Technology in June 2017. He is currently a Ph.D. candidate at Shanghai University, under the supervision of Prof. Wenxian Li. His research focuses on the design and synthesis of molybdenum based catalysts for their electrochemical hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen evolution reaction, and overall water splitting. Riyue Ge received his Ph.D. degree from the School of Materials Science and Engineering at Shanghai University, China, under the supervision of Prof. Wenxian Li. He is currently a postdoctoral research fellow at Shanghai University. His research interests focus on the synthesis, and characterization of functional nanomaterials for photo/electrochemical applications, including hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen evolution reaction, and overall water splitting. Jack Yang is currently a lecturer in the School of Materials Science and Engineering at The University of New South Wales, Australia. He received his BSc (2007) and Ph.D. (2011) from the same institute. Before returning to UNSW in 2017, he was a postdoctoral fellow in Westfälische Wilhelms-Universität Münster, Germany and the University of Southampton, UK. His current research focuses on theory and machine-learning-driven material studies on functional perovskites for electronic, photovoltaic, and energy-conversion applications. Jiancheng Li enrolled as a master’s and doctoral degree candidate at Shanghai University in 2018 and 2020, respectively. His research focuses on the design and synthesis of nanostructured materials and their applications for energy conversion. Sean Li received his Ph.D. degree from The University of Auckland in 1998. He was subsequently appointed as an assistant professor at Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, and then joined The University of New South Wales in 2004. He is currently a director of UNSW Materials and Manufacturing Futures Institute. His research interest focuses on advanced functional complex oxides and their heterostructures. Ying Li is a Professor at the School for Materials Science and Engineering, Shanghai University. She received her Ph.D. from the National Chungnam University in 2001. She was a postdoctoral fellow at the Research Materials Research Center of Chungnam National University, South Korea, and National Chungnam University, South Korea from March 2001 to December 2002 and then joined Shanghai University as a professor. Her research activities include material chemistry, such as conductive molecules, conductive materials, and energy materials. Dr. Jiujun Zhang is a Professor in College at Shanghai University, and a former Principal Research Officer at the National Research Council of Canada (NRC). Dr. Zhang is a Fellow of the Canadian Academy of Engineering (CAE), Fellow of The Academy of Science of The Royal Society of Canada (FRSCCA), Fellow of The Engineering Institute of Canada (EIC), Fellow of the International Society of Electrochemistry (ISE), and Fellow of the Royal Society of Chemistry (RSC-UK). Dr. Zhang received his B.S. and M.Sc. in Electrochemistry from Peking University in 1982 and 1985, respectively, and his Ph.D. in Electrochemistry from Wuhan University in 1988. Dr. Zhang’s main research areas are Electrochemistry, Electrocatalysts, Fuel cells, Lithium batteries, Metal-air batteries, Supercapacitors, and H2O/CO2/N2 electrolysis. Jing Feng is a professor at Kunming University of Science and Technology. He received his Ph.D. degree from the Tsinghua University & Kunming University of Science and Technology. He worked at Harvard University and researched high-temperature thermal barrier coatings. His current research involves the use of MGI to explore high-temperature ceramics (rare earth Tantanlate, RE-Ta-O system) and bonding coating alloys. Bin Liu is a professor at Shanghai University. He received his Ph.D. degree from the Institute of Metal Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences. His current research involves the use of various modelling and simulation techniques to explore the structure-function relationship of high-temperature ceramics. Wenxian Li is a Professor at the School for Materials Science and Engineering, Shanghai University. Dr. Li received his Ph.D. from the University of Wollongong, Australia, in 2010. He got the Australian Postdoctoral Fellowship (Industrial) supported by the Australian Research Council in 2012 and then got financial support from the Australian Renewable Energy Agency as a Postdoctoral Fellowship. He joined the University of Western Sydney as a lecturer in the Solar Energy Technologies Group in November 2012. His research focuses on the electron configuration modulation induced performance optimization of function materials for renewable energy utilization.

coredata.dc:description: Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2)-based materials as the non-noble metal catalysts have displayed the potential capability to drive electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) for green hydrogen production along with their intrinsic activity, tunable electronic properties, low cost, and abundance reserves, which have attracted intensive attention as alternatives to the low-abundance and high-cost platinum-based catalysts. However, their insufficient catalytic HER activities and stability are the major challenges for them to become practically applicable. Hereby, the MoS2-based electrocatalysts for HER are comprehensively reviewed to explain the fundamental science behind the manipulations of the crystal structure, microstructure, surface, and interface of MoS2 in order to enhance its catalytic performance through changing the electrical conductivity, the number of active sites, surface wettability, and the Gibbs free energy for hydrogen adsorption (ΔG H). Recent studies in surface/interface engineering, such as phase engineering, defect engineering, morphology design, and heterostructure construction, are analyzed to reveal the state-of-the-art strategies for designing and preparing the cost-effective and high-performance MoS2-based catalysts through optimizing the charge transfer, surface-active sites, ΔG H, and surface hydrophilicity. Lastly, the perspectives, challenges, and future research directions of HER electrocatalysis are also given to facilitate the further research and development of HER catalysts.
